all_paragraphs: Database Testing is a vital component to the implementation of any data system, regardless of industry. Implementing a database for employees of all roles to interact with on a daily basis requires that all data stored and retrieved, whether via SQL query or some sort of UI, is accurate — or else the database itself is essentially worthless. After the database is created, it is vital that it is then tested for functionality to ensure a robust application. Testing will ensure that the schema, tables, triggers, and the data integrity itself all are consistent and that every action is validated.
There are primarily three types of database testing:

The validation of all elements inside the data repository which are primarily not meant for use by the end users. This step involves database components like the servers and other data storage components such as column testing, schema testing, stored procedures/views testing, and trigger testing.

The schema is essentially the map of our database and it provides vital directions for the actual query process that allows us to fetch accurate data. Schema testing will allow us to ensure that the schema mapping is similar on both the back-end and the front-end of the application.
When schema testing we must ensure:

Example: If we have a schema that involves a set of tables, making changes in a singular table’s structure should be efficiently accommodated for in all resulting queries that rely on that changed table.
In this testing step, we must validate that the structures of the database and its feature columns are consistent.
When you think “trigger”, think of a chain reaction. Trigger testing ensures that the procedural flow of database code is in working order and without bugs.
These tests all revolve around the hosting server’s ability to manage the requests it will be getting.
This step essentially validates that when the user executes a query or interface request, the correct result will be retrieved and displayed for the user.

This point of testing requires that any and all of the transactions or operations which will be performed by end users are consistent with any requirements there are by the business and that they can all be efficiently and accurately executed.

This type of testing requires the verification of database integration for checking function. The tests will verify the integrity of data that is both incoming from the user, as well as any data being produced by the function. Some examples of black box tests:

These tests focus on the internal structure of the database not seen by the user. Modules within the database are stressed along with triggers, views, and some queries. The tables, schema, and models within the database will be validated using default table values to verify consistency throughout the entire database. In this process, bugs and other errors in code are usually spotted and reconciled. Some examples of White Box Testing:

Non-functional testing is essentially the performance testing of our database. These tests are completed to correspond with the business requirements and it will help see whether the actual result is in accordance with the expected result. Things like response time under stressful conditions are accounted for in this step.
This type of testing will check if any running transactions have impacts on the overall performance of the database.

In a stress test, we are trying to overload the workload of the application to determine the points of failure (the breakpoint). These points can then be addressed for improvement or highlighting for the end user. Usually, a third party stress testing tool is used.

For example, if an ERP application is advised to take a maximum of 20,000 users at any given time, the stress tester will gradually increase the workload beyond that maximum to determine at which point the application begins to fail. These benchmarks can be minded to when documentation is being organized for the end-user.

There are numerous methods for performing database tests and oftentimes companies will have employees with the sole responsibility of testing data. Understanding and using these procedures will allow for any data-user to create and use robust database applications that meet all functional requirements from both the business and the end-user.
